d:sect1.d:title: Angles and their Measures
d:sect1.d:para: The word Trigonometry comes from Greek(τριγωνομετρία) which includes two words; τριγωνο meaning triangle and μέτρηση which means measurement. The objective of studying plane Trigonometry is to develop a method of solving plane triangles. However, as time changes everything it has changed the scope of Trigonometry to include polygons and circles as well. A lot of concepts in this book will come from your Geometry classes in lower classes. It is a good idea to review the concepts which you have studied till now without which you are going to struggle while studying Trigonometry in this book.

If we consider a line extending to infinity in both directions, and a point O which divides this line in two parts one on each side of the point each part is called a ray or half-line. Thus, O divides it into two rays or half line OA and OA'. The point O is called the vertex or the origin of these rays. An angle is formed by two rays having common vertex or origin and denoted by ∠. The rays forming the angle are called sides of the angle.

An angle is written with symbol ∠ and three capital letters of which middle one represents the origin or vertex and other two represent two points on side. It is also written with the symbol and one letter representing origin.
An angle
The above angle is written as ∠AOB or ∠BOA. With each angle a measurement of angle is associated, which is a number, called degree of the angle.

Geometrical angles are always betweeen 0° and 360° and negative angles have no meaning in Geometry. Degree of rotation is smallest amount of rotation from the direction of one side to the direction of other side.

d:sect2.d:title: Angles in Trigonometry
d:sect2.d:para: The meaning of angle in Trigonometry is more general and it may be positive or negative. The initial position of the revolving side is called the initial side or arm and the final position is called terminal side or arm. The revolving line is called generating line or radius vector.

d:sect3.d:title: Angles Exceeding 360°
d:sect3.d:para:
In Geometry, angles are limited to 0° to 360°. However, when multiple revolutions are involved angles are more than 360°. For example, the revolving line starts from the initial position and makes n complete revolutions in anticlockwise direction and also further angle α in the same direction. We then have a certain angle βn given by βn=n×360°+α where 0°≤α≤360° and n is zero or positive integer. Thus, there are infinite possible angles.
A huge angle

d:sect3.d:title: Sign of angles
d:sect3.d:para: Angles formed by anticlockwise rotation of the radius vector are taken as positive and angles formed by clockwise rotation of the radius vector are taken as negative.

d:sect3.d:title: Quadrants
d:sect3.d:para:
Quadrants
Let XOX' and YOY' be two mutually perpendicular lines in a plane and OX be the initial half line. The lines divide the whole reason in quadrants. XOY,YOX',X'OY' and X'OX are respectively called 1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th quadrants. According to terminal side lying in 1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th quadrants the angles are said to be in 1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th quadrants respectively. A quandrant angle is an angle formed if terminal side coincides with one of the axes.

For any angle α which is not a quadrant angle and when number of revolutions is zero and radius vector rotates in anticlockwise directions:
0°<α<90° if α lies in the first quadrant
90°<α<180° if α lies in the second quadrant
180°<α<270° if α lies in the third quadrant
270°<α<360° if α lies in the fourth quadrant
when terminal side lies on OY, angle formed =90°
when terminal side lies on OX', angle formed =180°
when terminal side lies on OY', angle formed =270°
when terminal side lies on OX, angle formed =360°

d:sect2.d:title: Units of Measurement
d:sect2.d:para:
In Geometry, angles are usually measured in terms of right angles, however, that is an inconvenient system for smaller angles. So we introduce different systems of measurements. There are three system of units for this:
Sexagecimal or British system
In British system, a right angle is divided into 90 equal parts called degrees.
Each degree is then divided into 60 equal parts called minutes and each minute is further is divided into 60 parts called seconds.
A degree, a minute and a second are denoted by 1°,1'' and 1' respectively.
Centesimal or French System
In French system, a right angle is divided into 100 equal parts called grades.
Each grade is then divided into 1000 equal parts called minutes and each minute is further is divided into 100 parts called seconds.
A degree, a minute and a second are denoted by 1g,1'' and 1' respectively.
Radian or Circular Measure
An arc equal to radius of a circle when subtends an anngle on the center then that angle is 1 radian and is denoted by 1c. The angle made by half of perimeter is π radians. Also, from Geometry we know that angle subtended is the ratio between length of cord and radius. This ratio is in radians. Since both length or chord and radius have same unit radian is a constant.

d:sect3.d:title: Relationship between Systems of Measurements
d:sect3.d:para: If measure of an angle if D degrees, G grades and C radians then upon elementary manipulation we find that D180=G200=Cπ

d:sect3.d:title: Meaning of π
d:sect3.d:para: The ratio of circumference and diameter of a circle is always constant and this constant is denoted by gree letter π.

π is an irrational number. In general, we use the value of 227 but 355113 is more accurate though not exact. Thus, if r be the radius of a circle and c be the circumference then c2r=π leading circumference to be c=2πr
